did.unittitle: University of Pittsburgh, Board of Trustees, Meeting Minutes

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: University of Pittsburgh. Board of Trustees

did.abstract: This collection contains the meeting minutes of the Board of Trustees of the Western University of Pennsylvania from April 1845 to June 1908 and its successor, the University of Pittsburgh, from July 1908 to the present.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Based on the provisions of the September 12, 1974, Pennsylvania Sunshine Act, meetings of the Board of Trustees were designated as either "public" or "information" meetings. While minutes of public Board and committee meetings may be accessed by researchers immediately, minutes of information meetings are closed to researchers for a period of twenty-five years per the University's "Policy on Access to the Board of Trustees Files" signed by Chancellor Wesley W. Posvar on July 25, 1980.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Only the first one hundred years of the meeting minutes are currently processed.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: University of Pittsburgh, Board of Trustees, Meeting Minutes, 1845-present, UA.1.4, University of Pittsburgh Archives

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: University of Pittsburgh, Board of Trustees, Meeting Minutes, 1845-present, UA.1.4, University Archives, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: On February 28, 1787, the Pennsylvania Assembly approved an act creating the Pittsburgh Academy, which stipulated that the school's Board of Trustees would include "twenty-one members, seven of whom shall be a board or quorum to transact all the business of the said Academy." The newly established school's trustees included several prominent members of the community, including Col. Presley Neville and Nathaniel Bedford.

On February 18, 1819, the Commonwealth approved another act incorporating the Western University of Pennsylvania (WUP), citing the desire of the trustees of the Pittsburgh Academy to found a university in Pittsburgh. This act stipulated that the Trustees of WUP should consist of "twenty-six Trustees, nine of whom shall form a quorum or board." George Stevenson of Pittsburgh was elected to serve as the first President of the Board of Trustees of the University. Because several of the trustees were unable to attend meetings of the Board, an Act of Assembly was issued on March 9, 1826, to convene a new Board of Trustees. A March 6, 1872, supplement to the act of incorporation expanded the Board of Trustees to thirty-three members and included the mayors of Pittsburgh and Allegheny, as well as the Chancellor of the University. This supplement also stated that the Board would annually elect a president, treasurer, and secretary, the latter of which could not be a trustee. In addition, it established an Executive Committee consisting of the President and six additional annually elected trustees to act while the Board was not in session.

At the request of the Board of Trustees, the Western University of Pennsylvania changed its name to the University of Pittsburgh in 1908. In 1949, the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees was expanded to nine total members. In March 1960, the membership of the Board was amended to consist of: twelve Charter Trustees, at least one of which had to be an alumnus; nine Alumni Trustees that served three year terms with the ability to serve one succeeding consecutive term; nine Term Trustees that served three year terms with the ability to serve one succeeding consecutive term; and two ex officio members, the Mayor of Pittsburgh and the Chancellor of the University. At age seventy-two, a trustee could be elected as an Emeritus Trustee for life. Also at this time, the Executive Committee was expanded to nine elected members and the Chairman.

In September 1966, the Board of Trustees approved changes to the University's by-laws to make it a state-related school. Additionally, the composition of the Board was changed to include twenty-four University Trustees, including eleven Charter Trustees, six Term Trustees, and 6 Alumni Trustees. The Chancellor was appointed as one of the University Trustees. Also included were twelve Commonwealth Trustees, of which the Governor of Pennsylvania, President pro-tempore of the State Senate, and Speaker of the State house each appoint four individuals. The Governor, Mayor of Pittsburgh, and the State Superintendent of Public Instruction were made ex officio members.

On September 12, 1974, Pennsylvania's Open Meetings Law, often referred to as the Sunshine Act, stipulated that meetings of the Board of Trustees would be open to the public and that minutes of the meetings would be made available for public review. In order to conduct confidential business, the Board could convene information meetings, which were not open to the public. In 1987, an amendment to the Sunshine Act stated that public committee meeting minutes were also made available to the public.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in chronological order.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Minutes are periodically transferred to the University Archives from the Office of the Board of Trustees Secretery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the meeting minutes of the Board of Trustees of the Western University of Pennsylvania from April 1845 to June 1908 and its successor, the University of Pittsburgh, from July 1908 to the present. [Note: this finding aid only currently provides access to historic minutes from 1845-1945.]

Minutes of Board of Trustees meetings held prior to April 1845 were destroyed by a fire. Also, while the minutes in this collection may include reports from Board of Trustees committees, such as the Executive and Facilities Committees, the minutes of committee meetings are not present.

In addition to meeting minutes, this collection also includes supporting documentation that is referenced during meetings. This may include correspondence, treasurer reports, and lists of students confirmed by the Board for graduation, among others.
